docs.title: Welcome to BrahmWiki
docs.text: This repository contains a collection of embedded systems projects and libraries, focusing on RTOS-based development for ESP32, ATmega328P, and ATmega2560 microcontrollers.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
• Libraries: Explore the available libraries for communication and other peripherals.
  • Microcontrollers: Find specific information and examples for each supported microcontroller.

docs.title: Current Projects
docs.text: • RTOS Blink Examples: Simple "Blink LED" projects using a Real-Time Operating System (RTOS) for all three platforms, demonstrating the use of the custom serial library.

docs.title: Libraries
docs.text:
Welcome to the BrahmWiki library collection. Here you will find a growing collection of open-source libraries for a variety of microcontrollers and applications.

Use the navigation on the left to browse the available libraries by category.

docs.title: Standard UART Communication Library
docs.text: This library provides a standardized interface for UART communication across different microcontrollers, currently supporting ESP32 and AVR platforms.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Cross-platform: Write UART code once and use it on both ESP32 and AVR microcontrollers.
  • Standardized Functions: Provides a consistent API for initializing, writing to, and reading from UART ports.
  • Multiple UART Ports: Supports multiple UART ports on devices that have them (e.g., ATmega2560).

docs.title: void uart_init(uint8_t uart_num, uint32_t baud_rate)
docs.text:
Initializes the specified UART port with the given baud rate.

  • uart_num: The UART port to initialize (e.g., UART_0_PROG, UART_1_COMM).
  • baud_rate: The baud rate for the communication (e.g., 9600, 115200).

docs.title: void uart_write(uint8_t uart_num, const char *str)
docs.text:
Writes a null-terminated string to the specified UART port.

  • uart_num: The UART port to write to.
  • str: The string to send.

docs.title: int uart_read(uint8_t uart_num, uint8_t *buffer, uint32_t len)
docs.text:
Reads a specified number of bytes from the UART port into a buffer.

  • uart_num: The UART port to read from.
  • buffer: A pointer to the buffer where the data will be stored.
  • len: The maximum number of bytes to read.
  • Returns: The number of bytes read, or -1 on error.

docs.title: include "uart_standard.h"
docs.text:
void setup() { // Initialize UART 0 for programming/debugging at 115200 baud uart_init(UART_0_PROG, 115200); }

void loop() { uart_write(UART_0_PROG, "Hello, world!\n"); delay(1000); }

Use the navigation on the left to select a microcontroller and view its documentation.

docs.title: ATmega2560 Setup Guide
docs.text: 8-bit AVR microcontroller with more I/O

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Specification Details Architecture 8-bit AVR Operating Voltage 5V GPIO Pins 86 Analog Inputs 16

docs.title: Arduino IDE Setup
docs.text:
1. Install Arduino IDE
  2. Select Arduino Uno (ATmega328P) or Arduino Mega (ATmega2560)
  3. Connect via USB and select correct COM port

docs.title: Atmel Studio Setup
docs.text:
1. Download and install Atmel Studio
  2. Create new GCC C Executable Project
  3. Select ATmega2560 as target device
  4. Configure programmer (AVRISP, USBasp, etc.)

docs.title: ESP32 Setup Guide
docs.text: Dual-core 32-bit MCU with Wi-Fi & Bluetooth

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Specification Details Architecture 32-bit Xtensa Operating Voltage 3.3V GPIO Pins 34 Analog Inputs 18

docs.title: Arduino IDE Setup
docs.text:
1. Install Arduino IDE 2.0 or later
  2. Add ESP32 board manager URL: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/espressif/arduino-esp32/gh-pages/package_esp32_index.json
  3. Install ESP32 board package via Board Manager
  4. Select your ESP32 board from Tools > Board menu

platform = espressif32
board = esp32dev
framework = arduino
